facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 85-86 of 2002 are appeals by special leave directed against the judgment and order dated 13.11.2000 passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Madras

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL NOS. 85-86 OF 2002 These appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment and order dated 13.11.2000 passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Madras in respondents R.P Nos. 1280/1998 and 1281/1998 whereby the learned Single Judge has reversed the order passed by the First Appellate Court and maintained the judgment and decree granted by the Trial Court.

facts.text: High Court Single Judge passed judgment in respondents R.P Nos. 1280/1998 and 1281/1998

anchor.surface_text: passed by a learned Single Judge of the High Court of Madras in respondents R.P Nos. 1280/1998 and 1281/1998 whereby the learned Single Judge has reversed the order passed by the First Appellate Court and maintained the judgment and decree granted by the Trial Court.

facts.text: High Court Single Judge reversed the order passed by the First Appellate Court and maintained the judgment and decree granted by the Trial Court

anchor.surface_text: whereby the learned Single Judge has reversed the order passed by the First Appellate Court and maintained the judgment and decree granted by the Trial Court. Brief facts which are necessary for the disposal of these appeals are that a suit was filed by the landlord-respondent herein for eviction of the tenant-appellant herein from the premises bearing Door No. 188  Old No. 112  at Jawaharlal Nehru Street, Pondicherry on the ground that the premises is very old and in a dilapidated companydition requiring demolition and that he has taken steps to get permission and approval from the companypetent authority for demolition and reconstruction.

facts.text: Landlord filed a suit for eviction of tenant from premises bearing Door No. 188 Old No. 112 at Jawaharlal Nehru Street, Pondicherry

He filed another suit on the ground that the tenant-appellant had ceased to occupy the demised premises under Section 10 2  vi  of the Pondicherry Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1969  hereinafter for short the Act .

He filed another suit on the ground that the tenant-appellant had ceased to occupy the demised premises under Section 10 2  vi  of the Pondicherry Buildings  Lease and Rent Control  Act, 1969  hereinafter for short the Act . The Trial Court decreed both the suits filed by the landlord-respondent and granted decree of eviction against the tenant-appellant herein.

facts.text: High Court found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in exercise of power under Section 25 of the act has found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it. Therefore, the High Court has rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority and affirmed the judgment and decree of eviction granted by the Trial Court in the suit.

In these circumstances, we are of the opinion that the High Court has under Section 25 of the Act rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority. Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.

arguments.claim: Under Section 25 of the Act, the High Court could not have reversed the finding of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that under Section 25 of the Act a revision petition is maintainable before the High Court and in revision the High Court could not have reversed the finding of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court. In support of his submission, he has placed reliance on a decision of this Court in the case of M. Punnoose Vs. K.M. Munneruddin and Others 2003 10 SCC 610.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d the finding of fact recorded by the First Appellate Court. In support of his submission, he has placed reliance on a decision of this Court in the c

arguments.court_reasoning: Scope of Section 25 is wide, not as narrow as CPC Section 115; allows examination of correctness, legality, propriety including facts; High Court rightly interfered given building's age and cracks

arguments.claim: Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Act and confers wide revisional jurisdiction on the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is true that Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with the Tamil Nadu Lease and Rent Control Act, 1960 hereinafter for short the Tamil Nadu Act. Section 25 of the Tamil Nadu Act came up for consideration before this Court in the case of P.M. Punnoose supra where this Court held that the revisional jurisdiction conferred upon the High Court is not as narrow as one under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure nevertheless a finding of fact arrived at by the Appellate Authority cannot be lightly interfered with by the High Court acting like a court of appeal and reappreciating the evidence.

arguments.claim: Scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 CPC and allows High Court to examine appellate record for correctness, legality or propriety including facts

anchor.surface_text: The provision of Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with the Tamil Nadu Act and we are of the opinion that the approach of the High Court is correct. The scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly.

arguments.claim: High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with Appellate Authority's finding as building is 60 years old and has cracks

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in exercise of power under Section 25 of the act has found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it. Therefore, the High Court has rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority and affirmed the judgment and decree of eviction granted by the Trial Court in the suit.

arguments.claim: High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with finding of fact by Appellate Authority; appeals fail and are dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we are of the opinion that the High Court has under Section 25 of the Act rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority. Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.

arguments.claim: No useful purpose served by deciding eviction under Section 10(2)(vi) since upheld on Section 25 ground

anchor.surface_text: Since, we have upheld the judgment and order of the High Court on the ground of Section 25 of the Act, we think no useful purpose will be served by going into another issue where the decree of eviction was granted on the ground that the appellant ceased to occupy the premises in terms of Section 10 2 vi.

holdings.text: The scope of Section 25 of the Act is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and allows the High Court to examine the record for regularity, correctness, legality or propriety of decisions, including facts, and to modify, annul, reverse or remit them.

anchor.surface_text: The provision of Section 25 of the Act is almost pari materia with the Tamil Nadu Act and we are of the opinion that the approach of the High Court is correct. The scope of Section 25 is not as narrow as Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The expression used in Section 25 of the Act is that the High Court can examine the record of the appellate authority, to satisfy itself as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and if, in any case, it appears to the High Court that any such decision or order should be modified, annulled, reversed or remitted for reconsideration, it may pass orders accordingly. Therefore, the scope of Section 25 of the Act is very wide as the High Court can under this provision examine the record of the appellate authority as to the regularity of such proceeding or the correctness, legality or propriety of any decision or order passed therein and can modify, annul, reverse or remit for reconsideration. This expression in the Act has a wide import and the very fact that the High Court can examine the correctness, legality or propriety of the order necessarily goes to show that the High Court has power to examine the matter with reference to facts also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of Section 25's language empowering broad examination including propriety which encompasses facts; pari materia with TN Act S25 as per precedent in P.M. Punnoose, approving High Court's approach despite caution against light interference.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 with the Appellate Authority's finding of fact as the building is about 60 years old and has developed cracks.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in exercise of power under Section 25 of the act has found that the building is about 60 years old and it has developed cracks in it. Therefore, the High Court has rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority and affirmed the judgment and decree of eviction granted by the Trial Court in the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of wide S25 power to specific facts of building's age and condition evidenced by cracks, justifying reversal of lower finding.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly interfered under Section 25 of the Act with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority; consequently, the appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we are of the opinion that the High Court has under Section 25 of the Act rightly interfered with the finding of fact recorded by the Appellate Authority. Consequently, these appeals fail and are dismissed as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirmation of High Court's justified interference based on circumstances and S25 scope, leading to dismissal of appeals.

holdings.text: No useful purpose will be served by deciding the eviction ground under Section 10(2)(vi) since the High Court's judgment is upheld on Section 25 ground.

anchor.surface_text: Since, we have upheld the judgment and order of the High Court on the ground of Section 25 of the Act, we think no useful purpose will be served by going into another issue where the decree of eviction was granted on the ground that the appellant ceased to occupy the premises in terms of Section 10 2 vi .

holdings.reasoning_summary: One sufficient ground for upholding eviction makes alternative ground unnecessary to decide.
